abstracts.cdata!:
The Wider Caribbean Initiative on Ship
            Generated Waste Project was innovative - it was the first
            time that the Bank has been directly concerned with the
            implementation of the International Convention for the
            Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARIPOL 73/78), as well
            as the first time the Bank has worked with the International
            Maritime Organization (IMO). The project, judged as
            satisfactory with a likely sustainability, learned the
            following lessons: a) there was an underestimation of time
            required to reach consensus among the 22 involved countries;
            b) better definition of respective responsibilities for
            supervision and procurement were needed prior to signing; c)
            more intensive involvement of the Bank's legal and
            environmental specialists would have improved preparation;
            d) the IMO's appointment as executing agency imposed a
            barrier between the Bank and the beneficiary countries; e)
            in the absence of a region-wide suitable institution,
            special attention should have been given to the involvement
            of suitable sub-regional institutions; f) when a project
            represents a new area of work for the Bank, a formal
            mid-term review should have been included in the Project
            Document; g) the decision to close was based on the
            Bank's judgement that agreed deadlines were not
            achieved and in the face of the "inability" of the
            IMO to follow agreed procedures and action; and h) the Bank
            should continue to support the efforts of IMO and
            governments to implement and sustain MARPOL 73/78.
